TITLE:
   Chief Complaint: NSTEMI/Flash PE/Afib with RVR
   24 Hour Events:
   Afib with RVR around 0030 with rate to the 130s, and hypotensive with
   Maps in  high 50s;
   Gave 5 mg bolus of dilt, maxed out dilt gtt to 20 mg/hr...hypotensive
   with maps in 50s, increased neo to 1.2...finally broke...started

   HEENT:  Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor

   NECK: Supple with JVP of difficult to estimate [**1-28**] habitus.
   CARDIAC: NSR, RR, normal S1, S2. No m/r/g.
   LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Course breath
   sounds bilaterally in anterior lung fields.
   ABDOMEN: Soft, obese, NTND. No HSM or tenderness.

   mg/dL, PO4:3.5 mg/dL
   Lipid Panel: Pending; AST/ALT; Pending
   Sputum Gram Stain: oropharyngeal flora
   Blood Cx, Urine Cx, Sputum Cx: all pending
   CXR:
   The hila are prominent, with additional confluent perihilar opacities,
   as well as patchy opacity
   at the left base and peripherally in the left midlung. Findings may
   represent a combination of perihilar
   edema and adenopathy/chronic interstitial changes from patient's known
   sarcoid, but superimposed pneumonia cannot be excluded.
   CXR this AM pending
   Assessment and Plan
   72 yo female h/o DM, HLD, HTN, Afib with RVR, s/p pacemaker and sarcoid
   presents  with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema.
   Patient also with AFib with RVR causing hypotension. Also with mild
   troponin increase of 0.12 (peaked at 0.27 in OSH), ischemic changes on
   EKG (TWI) : Sent for cath and found 2 vessel disease, s/p BMS to LAD.
   .
   # CORONARIES: NSTEMI: found to have 2 vessel disease on cardiac cath.
   s/p BMS to the mid LAD. ? whether this was a primary coronary event or
   demand [**1-28**] RVR as pt. had acute heart failure yesterday and still has
   not significantly increased her troponin, would have expected large
   bump by now if infarct large enough to cause LV failure. EKG does
   appear to be c/w s/p anterior infarct.
   -Integrillin gtt until 18 hours post cath (stop at 1100)
   -Plavix 75 mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Start Aspirin desensitisation protocal
   - Simvistatin 80 mg daily
   - Start metroprolol low dose later today.
   -Hold ACE for now, given her hypotension and dye in cath
   - TTE in am to check for WMA
   .
   # PUMP: Noted to have EF of 60-70% on [**5-27**]. Current BNP elevated to
   [**Numeric Identifier 8933**].  Fluid overload possibly secondary afib with RVR; this is likely
   the etiology behind her flash pulmonary edema.
   -Will hold diuresis as patient is hypotensive and on Phenylephrine
   -Once stable, will consider diuresing
   -FU TTE today
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient with h/o afib with RVR, presents to unit in afib with
   RVR and hemodynamically unstable.
   -Dilt gtt started, bolus of 20 mg with infusion of [**5-15**] mg/hr as
   tolerated maintain HR < 110;
   - Since patient has a DDD pacemaker, will give as much nodal agents as
   needed for RVR, as patient will be paced out of bradycardia.
   - Neo gtt to maintain MAP > 60
   - Start low dose metroprolol later today after ASA desensitization.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - INR elevated to 2.3; continue home dose of coumadin as patient is at
   goal, but will hold heparin gtt.
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Intubated s/p flash pulmonary edema in OSH;
   possibly secondary to Acute dCHF
   -intubated on AC; Will attempt PS today and ultimately wean from vent
   when HD stable; RISBI overnight was 29
   - Check ABG's in AM
   - Start Lasix 20 mg IV, FU I/Os adjust as needed.
   - CXR in AM
   -  Attempt extubation today.
   # Respiratory Acidosis with Metabolic Compensation: Patient h/o COPD on
   home oxygen secondary to sarcoidosis. Acid/Base disturbance likely
   secondary to COPD, as patient may be a CO2 retainer.
   -Continue to monitor with ABG's
   -Adjust major acid/base disturbances with ventilation manipulation
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Patient had wbc in OSH of 8.4 on [**7-15**], currently  24.2.
   Patient spiked to 101.1, and CXR shows new middle lobe infilitrate.
   Also, C.diff cannot be ruled out as pt. w/ h/o diarrhea and acutely
   high WBC.
   - BCX, UCx and sputum culture, and C. diff toxin pending
   -Will start empiric treatment of VAP since new infiltrate shown on CXR;
   will start 7 day course of vanc/cefepime: will need ID approval
   -Since white count is markedly elevated and patient has h/o diarrhea,
   cannot exclude C. diff. Will start empiric treatment with flaygl
   pending c. diff toxin results.
   .
   # Sarcoidosis: On home O2 3LNC; currently stable; patient intubated
   - Continue Prednisone 5 mg qAM and 2.5 mg qPM
   - H/o hypercalcemia -> will continue fosamax q weekly
   .
   # Diabetes type 2: Will hold metformin and glipizide for now
   -Start humulog ISS for more predictable control
   -FSBS qachs
   .
   # Dyslipidemia: Do not have recent lipid panel.
   -Will hold zetia
   -Will check lipid panel this AM
   -Start simvistatin 80 mg daily
   # HTN: patient currently hypotensive
   -Currently normotensive.
   # Hypothyroidism:
   -Continue Synthroid at 25 mcg daily
   # Depression:
   -Continue Paroxetine 10 mg daily
   # GERD:
   -Start H2 blocker (Famotidine) as PPI interacts with Plavix
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO for now; if fails weaning today, consider tube feeds;
   if successful extubation, attempt po diet
   Glycemic Control:  ISS
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2182-7-16**] 07:06 PM left femoral
   20 Gauge - [**2182-7-17**] 12:50 AM
   Consider PICC line.
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:  boots, therapeutic INR
   Stress ulcer:  Famotidine 20 mg daily
   VAP:  HOB 30 degrees
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:  Husband [**Name (NI) 135**] [**Name (NI) 2415**]: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8934**] (health
   care proxy)
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:  CCU for now
   ------ Protected Section ------
   Cardiology Teaching Physician Note
   On this day I saw, examined and was physically present with the
   resident / fellow for the key portions of the services provided. I
   agree with the above note and plans.
   I would add the following remarks:
   History
   Rapid af leading to troponin elevation in setting of a tight distal lad
   lesion that was stented.  She has severe mulitiorgan sarcoidosis with
   muiltiple potential cardiac manifestation including heart block (at one
   time) requiring ddd pacer, atrial arrhythmias for which she was on
   sotalol for a while; even her cad could possibly be from sarcoid but
   obviously most likely from her usual risk factors of htn,
   hyperlipidemia, obesity, age, and diabetes.  I suspect that her atrial
   arrhythmias will be difficult to manage so we should get an eps
   consult.
   Physical Examination
   echo shows apical hk of the lv and apical akinesis of the rv with
   severe pulm htn (interestingly the rhc demonstrated only mild elevation
   of pulm vasc resistance which means that most of the blame for the pulm
   htn rests on diastolic dysfunction of the left ventricle)
   Medical Decision Making
   Since it is of paramount importance to maintain sinus rhythm (or at
   very least a well-controlled ventricular rate in af), and since she has
   lung disease possibly precluding the drug of choice (amiodarone), we
   will get an eps consult.
   ------ Protected Section Addendum Entered By:[**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) **]  on:[**2182-7-17**]

Based on the provided daily progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), sarcoidosis, and a pacemaker. She presents to the ICU with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.1°C (98.8°F)
* Heart rate: 69 beats per minute (bpm) with a sinus rhythm
* Blood pressure: 87/36 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 17 inspirations per minute (insp/min)
* Oxygen saturation: 96%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 60 mmHg

The patient's lab results show:

* Troponin: 0.12 ng/mL (peaked at 0.27 ng/mL in the outpatient setting)
* Creatine kinase (CK): 64 IU/L
* Creatine kinase-MB (CK-MB): 0.14 ng/mL
* Pro-B-type natriuretic peptide (proBNP): [**Numeric Identifier 8933**] ng/mL
* White blood cell count (WBC): 24.2 K/μL
* Hematocrit (Hct): 35.1%
* Platelet count (Plt): 288 K/μL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 29.5 mg/dL
* Serum creatinine (Cr): 1.1 mg/dL
* Glucose: 192 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination shows:

* General: Intubated, sedated
* HEENT: Sclera anicteric, pink conjunctiva, and no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa
* Neck: Supple with a difficult-to-estimate jugular venous pressure (JVP)
* Cardiac: Normal sinus rhythm, regular rate, and normal S1 and S2 sounds
* Lungs: Course breath sounds bilaterally in the anterior lung fields
* Abdomen: Soft, obese, and non-tender
* Extremities: No calf tenderness or edema
* Skin: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas

The patient's medical history and current condition suggest the following potential medical complications:

1. Cardiac complications:
	* Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR) may lead to hypotension, flash pulmonary edema, and cardiac arrhythmias.
	* The patient's history of sarcoidosis may increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as heart block, atrial arrhythmias, and cardiac fibrosis.
2. Respiratory complications:
	* Flash pulmonary edema may lead to respiratory failure and require mechanical ventilation.
	* The patient's history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and sarcoidosis may increase the risk of respiratory complications, such as respiratory acidosis and hypercapnia.
3. Infectious complications:
	* The patient's elevated white blood cell count (WBC) and fever may indicate an underlying infection, such as pneumonia or sepsis.
	* The patient's history of diarrhea and acutely elevated WBC count may suggest a diagnosis of Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) infection.
4. Metabolic complications:
	* The patient's history of diabetes and hyperlipidemia may increase the risk of metabolic complications, such as hyperglycemia, hyperkalemia, and hyperphosphatemia.
	* The patient's current medications, such as simvastatin and metformin, may interact with other medications or worsen underlying metabolic conditions.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

1. Cardiovascular medications:
	* Diltiazem for rate control and prevention of atrial fibrillation
	* Metoprolol for heart rate control and reduction of cardiac workload
	* Aspirin for antiplatelet therapy
	* Plavix for antiplatelet therapy
2. Respiratory support:
	* Mechanical ventilation for respiratory failure
	* Oxygen therapy for hypoxemia
3. Infectious disease management:
	* Empiric treatment for pneumonia or sepsis
	* Antimicrobial therapy for C. diff infection
4. Metabolic management:
	* Insulin therapy for hyperglycemia
	* Medications for hyperkalemia and hyperphosphatemia

The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications. The patient's family should be informed of the patient's condition and treatment plan, and the patient's code status should be discussed and documented.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old female with a complex medical history, including diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and sarcoidosis, who presents with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. She has a history of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR) and has undergone cardiac catheterization with placement of a bare-metal stent (BMS) in the mid-left anterior descending (LAD) artery.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Respiratory failure: Intubated due to flash pulmonary edema, possibly secondary to acute decompensated heart failure.
2. Cardiac arrhythmia: AFib with RVR, treated with diltiazem and neoepinephrine.
3. Hemodynamic instability: Hypotensive with a mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 51 mmHg.
4. Electrolyte imbalance: Elevated troponin (0.12 ng/mL) and creatinine (1.1 mg/dL).
5. Leukocytosis: White blood cell count (WBC) of 24.2 K/uL, with a marked increase from the previous day.
6. Sarcoidosis: On home oxygen therapy, with a history of hypercalcemia and hyperthyroidism.
7. Diabetes type 2: On metformin and glipizide, which will be held for now.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: Continued respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation, potentially leading to worsening pulmonary edema and decreased lung function.
2. Cardiac arrhythmia: AFib with RVR may persist or worsen, leading to further hemodynamic instability and potential cardiac arrest.
3. Electrolyte imbalance: Continued elevation of troponin and creatinine may indicate ongoing cardiac damage and potential kidney injury.
4. Leukocytosis: Marked increase in WBC count may indicate infection, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or sepsis.
5. Sarcoidosis: Continued inflammation and fibrosis may lead to worsening respiratory and cardiac dysfunction.
6. Diabetes type 2: Holding metformin and glipizide may lead to worsening glycemic control and potential diabetic ketoacidosis.

To address these potential complications, the patient requires close monitoring and management of her respiratory, cardiac, and metabolic status. This may involve adjustments to her ventilator settings, cardiac medications, and insulin therapy, as well as ongoing monitoring of her electrolyte and hematological profiles.

   72 yo female h/o DM, HLD, HTN, Afib with RVR, s/p pacemaker and sarcoid
   presents  with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema.
   Patient also with AFib with RVR causing hypotension. Also with mild
   troponin increase of 0.12 (peaked at 0.27 in OSH), ischemic changes on
   EKG (TWI) : Sent for cath and found 2 vessel disease, s/p BMS to LAD.
   .
   # CORONARIES: NSTEMI: found to have 2 vessel disease on cardiac cath.
   s/p BMS to the mid LAD. ? whether this was a primary coronary event or
   demand [**1-28**] RVR as pt. had acute heart failure yesterday and still has
   not significantly increased her troponin, would have expected large
   bump by now if infarct large enough to cause LV failure. EKG does
   appear to be c/w s/p anterior infarct.
   -Integrillin gtt until 18 hours post cath (stop at 1100)
   -Plavix 75 mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Start Aspirin desensitisation protocal
   - Simvistatin 80 mg daily
   - Start metroprolol low dose later today.
   -Hold ACE for now, given her hypotension and dye in cath
   - TTE in am to check for WMA
   .
   # PUMP: Noted to have EF of 60-70% on [**5-27**]. Current BNP elevated to
   [**Numeric Identifier 8933**].  Fluid overload possibly secondary afib with RVR; this is likely
   the etiology behind her flash pulmonary edema.
   -Will hold diuresis as patient is hypotensive and on Phenylephrine
   -Once stable, will consider diuresing
   -FU TTE today
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient with h/o afib with RVR, presents to unit in afib with
   RVR and hemodynamically unstable.
   -Dilt gtt started, bolus of 20 mg with infusion of [**5-15**] mg/hr as
   tolerated maintain HR < 110;
   - Since patient has a DDD pacemaker, will give as much nodal agents as
   needed for RVR, as patient will be paced out of bradycardia.
   - Neo gtt to maintain MAP > 60
   - Start low dose metroprolol later today after ASA desensitization.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - INR elevated to 2.3; continue home dose of coumadin as patient is at
   goal, but will hold heparin gtt.
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Intubated s/p flash pulmonary edema in OSH;
   possibly secondary to Acute dCHF
   -intubated on AC; Will attempt PS today and ultimately wean from vent
   when HD stable; RISBI overnight was 29
   - Check ABG's in AM
   - Start Lasix 20 mg IV, FU I/Os adjust as needed.
   - CXR in AM
   -  Attempt extubation today.
   # Respiratory Acidosis with Metabolic Compensation: Patient h/o COPD on
   home oxygen secondary to sarcoidosis. Acid/Base disturbance likely
   secondary to COPD, as patient may be a CO2 retainer.
   -Continue to monitor with ABG's
   -Adjust major acid/base disturbances with ventilation manipulation
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Patient had wbc in OSH of 8.4 on [**7-15**], currently  24.2.
   Patient spiked to 101.1, and CXR shows new middle lobe infilitrate.
   Also, C.diff cannot be ruled out as pt. w/ h/o diarrhea and acutely
   high WBC.
   - BCX, UCx and sputum culture, and C. diff toxin pending
   -Will start empiric treatment of VAP since new infiltrate shown on CXR;
   will start 7 day course of vanc/cefepime: will need ID approval
   -Since white count is markedly elevated and patient has h/o diarrhea,
   cannot exclude C. diff. Will start empiric treatment with flaygl
   pending c. diff toxin results.
   .
   # Sarcoidosis: On home O2 3LNC; currently stable; patient intubated
   - Continue Prednisone 5 mg qAM and 2.5 mg qPM
   - H/o hypercalcemia -> will continue fosamax q weekly
   .
   # Diabetes type 2: Will hold metformin and glipizide for now
   -Start humulog ISS for more predictable control
   -FSBS qachs
   .
   # Dyslipidemia: Do not have recent lipid panel.
   -Will hold zetia
   -Will check lipid panel this AM
   -Start simvistatin 80 mg daily
   # HTN: patient currently hypotensive
   -Currently normotensive.
   # Hypothyroidism:
   -Continue Synthroid at 25 mcg daily
   # Depression:
   -Continue Paroxetine 10 mg daily
   # GERD:
   -Start H2 blocker (Famotidine) as PPI interacts with Plavix
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO for now; if fails weaning today, consider tube feeds;
   if successful extubation, attempt po diet
   Glycemic Control:  ISS

Based on the provided daily progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old female with a complex medical history, including diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and sarcoidosis, who presented to the ICU with acute heart failure, flash pulmonary edema, and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR). 

The patient's condition has been managed with various medications, including diltiazem, eptifibatide, and metoprolol, as well as interventions such as cardioversion and cardiac catheterization. The patient has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. 

The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and there is a risk of further deterioration, particularly if the patient is not weaned from mechanical ventilation.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of AFib with RVR and the presence of a pacemaker increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardia and fibrillation.
3. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and C-reactive protein level suggest the possibility of sepsis, particularly in light of the new infiltrate on the chest X-ray and the patient's history of diarrhea.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's elevated creatinine level and decreased urine output increase the risk of acute kidney injury.
5. Respiratory acidosis: The patient's chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and respiratory failure increase the risk of respiratory acidosis, which can be life-threatening if not managed properly.
6. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's diabetes and hyperlipidemia increase the risk of metabolic acidosis, which can be exacerbated by the patient's respiratory failure.
7. Infection: The patient's history of sarcoidosis and the presence of a central line and Foley catheter increase the risk of infection, particularly bacteremia and urinary tract infection.

To mitigate these risks, the patient requires close monitoring and management by the ICU team, including frequent assessments of her respiratory, cardiac, and renal status, as well as management of her medications and interventions.

   -Integrillin gtt until 18 hours post cath (stop at 1100)
   -Plavix 75 mg [**Hospital1 7**]; NO ASA b/c of allergy
   -Simvistatin 80 mg daily
   -Low dose metoprolol as patient tolerates
   -Hold ACE for now, given her hypotension and dye in cath
   - TTE in am to check for WMA
   .

   [**Numeric Identifier 8933**] -> HF possibly secondary to sarcoidosis vs. CAD;  Fluid overload
   possibly secondary to acute heart failure; this is likely the etiology
   behind her flash pulmonary edema, likely that AF acutely led to
   increased rate, decreased filling time and loss of atrial kick.
   -Will hold diuresis as patient is hypotensive and on Phenylephrine
   -Once stable, will consider diuresing
   -Repeat TTE tomorrow
   .

   RVR and hemodynamically unstable.
   -Dilt gtt started, bolus of 20 mg with infusion of [**5-15**] mg/hr as
   tolerated maintain HR < 110;

   - Hold Sotolol for now
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - INR elevated to 2.3; continue home dose of coumadin as patient is at
   goal, but will hold heparin gtt.
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Intubated s/p flash pulmonary edema in OSH;
   possibly secondary to Acute dCHF
   -intubated on AC; Will attempt PS today and ultimately wean from vent
   when HD stable; RISBI overnight was 29
   -Check ABG's in AM
   - Diurese when BP allows for better resolution of pulmonary edema
   - CXR in AM

   Also, C.diff cannot be ruled out as pt. w/ h/o diarrhea and acutely

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), and sarcoidosis. She presented to the hospital with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. The patient had a previous cardiac catheterization that revealed 2-vessel disease, and she underwent a stent placement in the mid-left anterior descending (LAD) artery.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 98.8°C, HR 69 bpm, BP 87/36 mmHg, RR 17 breaths/min, SpO2 96%
* Respiratory support: Intubated and mechanically ventilated with a tidal volume of 450 mL and a respiratory rate of 16 breaths/min
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's mean arterial pressure (MAP) is being maintained above 60 mmHg with the use of phenylephrine and dopamine infusions
* Cardiac rhythm: The patient's heart rhythm is currently in sinus rhythm, but she has a history of AFib with RVR
* Laboratory results: The patient's troponin level is mildly elevated at 0.12 ng/mL, and her creatinine level is elevated at 1.1 mg/dL
* Imaging studies: The patient's chest X-ray (CXR) shows prominent hilar opacities and patchy opacity at the left base, which may represent a combination of perihilar edema and adenopathy/chronic interstitial changes from her known sarcoidosis, but superimposed pneumonia cannot be excluded.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is already intubated and mechanically ventilated, and there is a risk of further respiratory deterioration
* Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of AFib with RVR and 2-vessel disease, which may lead to further cardiac complications such as heart failure or arrhythmias
* Sepsis: The patient has a high white blood cell count and is at risk of developing sepsis, particularly given her history of diarrhea and the presence of a new middle lobe infiltrate on her CXR
* C. difficile infection: The patient has a history of diarrhea and a high white blood cell count, which may increase her risk of developing C. difficile infection
* Hypercalcemia: The patient has a history of hypercalcemia, which may lead to further complications if not managed appropriately
* Hypothyroidism: The patient has a history of hypothyroidism, which may require further monitoring and management.

In terms of the patient's management plan, the following interventions are planned:

* Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and hemodynamic status
* Continue to administer dopamine and phenylephrine infusions to maintain MAP above 60 mmHg
* Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust her antiarrhythmic medication as necessary
* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust her ventilator settings as necessary
* Continue to monitor the patient's laboratory results and adjust her medication regimen as necessary
* Consider diuresis when the patient's blood pressure allows for better resolution of pulmonary edema
* Repeat TTE tomorrow to assess the patient's left ventricular function and estimate her left ventricular mass
* Consider empiric treatment of VAP if the patient's CXR shows new infiltrates or if she develops fever or leukocytosis
* Consider empiric treatment of C. difficile infection if the patient's symptoms worsen or if she develops diarrhea or abdominal pain.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and sarcoidosis, who presented to the ICU with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. She has a pacemaker and was diagnosed with NSTEMI, 2-vessel disease, and had a BMS placed in the mid-LAD.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hemodynamically unstable with hypotension and tachycardia
* Intubated for respiratory failure secondary to flash pulmonary edema
* On mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode
* Has a DDD pacemaker and is being treated for AFib with RVR
* Has mild troponin increase and ischemic changes on EKG
* Has a history of COPD and is on home oxygen
* Has leukocytosis with a WBC of 24.2 and is at risk for VAP and C. diff infection
* Has a history of sarcoidosis and is on prednisone and fosamax
* Has type 2 diabetes and is being treated with insulin
* Has dyslipidemia and is being treated with simvastatin
* Has hypertension and is being treated with Plavix and simvastatin
* Has hypothyroidism and is being treated with synthroid
* Has depression and is being treated with paroxetine
* Has GERD and is being treated with famotidine
* Has mild transaminitis and is being monitored with LFTs

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Cardiac complications: continued ischemia, worsening of heart failure, arrhythmias
* Respiratory complications: VAP, C. diff infection, respiratory failure
* Infection: sepsis, bacteremia
* Gastrointestinal complications: gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation
* Neurological complications: seizures, stroke
* Metabolic complications: hyperglycemia, hyperkalemia
* Cardiovascular complications: cardiac tamponade, cardiac arrest

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue diuresis as tolerated
* Monitor for signs of worsening heart failure
* Adjust ventilation settings as needed
* Continue antibiotics for VAP
* Monitor for signs of C. diff infection
* Continue prednisone and fosamax for sarcoidosis
* Monitor for signs of type 2 diabetes complications
* Monitor for signs of dyslipidemia complications
* Monitor for signs of hypertension complications
* Monitor for signs of hypothyroidism complications
* Monitor for signs of depression complications
* Monitor for signs of GERD complications
* Monitor for signs of mild transaminitis complications

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and sarcoidosis, who presented with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. She was intubated and has been experiencing episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR) and hypotension since admission. She has undergone cardiac catheterization and was found to have 2-vessel disease, which was treated with balloon angioplasty and stenting of the mid-left anterior descending artery. She has also been diagnosed with severe pulmonary hypertension and has been experiencing respiratory failure.

The patient has been receiving various medications, including diuretics, vasopressors, and antiarrhythmic agents, to manage her heart failure and arrhythmias. She has also been receiving antibiotics for a suspected infection and has had a positive blood culture for Gram-positive cocci.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of troponin, creatinine, and blood urea nitrogen, indicating possible kidney damage. Her liver function tests are also abnormal, with elevated levels of liver enzymes.

The patient's physical examination shows signs of heart failure, including jugular venous distension, bilateral pedal edema, and rales in the lungs. Her electrocardiogram shows a normal sinus rhythm with a rate of 76 beats per minute, and her chest x-ray shows a moderate amount of pulmonary edema.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of AFib with RVR and the presence of severe pulmonary hypertension increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias, including ventricular fibrillation and cardiac arrest.
2. Heart failure: The patient's heart failure is likely to worsen if she does not receive adequate treatment, including diuretics and vasopressors.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to worsen if she does not receive adequate ventilation and oxygenation.
4. Sepsis: The patient's positive blood culture and elevated white blood cell count increase the risk of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death.
5. Kidney damage: The patient's elevated levels of creatinine and blood urea nitrogen indicate possible kidney damage, which can worsen if she does not receive adequate treatment.
6. Liver damage: The patient's elevated levels of liver enzymes indicate possible liver damage, which can worsen if she does not receive adequate treatment.
7. Infection: The patient's positive blood culture and elevated white blood cell count increase the risk of infection, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust her medications as necessary to prevent cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Continue to manage the patient's heart failure with diuretics and vasopressors, and consider adding an inotrope if necessary.
3. Continue to provide respiratory support with mechanical ventilation and oxygenation, and consider adding a nitric oxide infusion if necessary.
4. Continue to treat the patient's suspected infection with antibiotics, and consider adding a second antibiotic if necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's kidney function and adjust her medications as necessary to prevent further kidney damage.
6. Monitor the patient's liver function and adjust her medications as necessary to prevent further liver damage.
7. Consider adding a stress dose of steroids to the patient's treatment regimen to prevent adrenal insufficiency.
8. Consider adding a pulmonary artery catheter to the patient's treatment regimen to monitor her pulmonary artery pressure and guide her treatment.
9. Consider adding a cardiac output monitor to the patient's treatment regimen to monitor her cardiac output and guide her treatment.
10. Consider adding a liver function test to the patient's treatment regimen to monitor her liver function and guide her treatment.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, I summarize the following information:

**Medical History:**

* The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), and sarcoidosis.
* She has a known allergy to inhalants (unknown type), terbutaline, and has a history of acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema.

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a diagnosis of acute respiratory failure and respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation.
* She has been experiencing episodes of AFib with RVR and hypotension since admission, and has been treated with Diltiazem and Phenylephrine.
* Her blood cultures grew GPC in clusters, and she has been started on empiric treatment for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and C. difficile colitis.
* Her renal function has deteriorated, with a current creatinine level of 1.5 mg/dL.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* The patient is at risk for continued hypotension and cardiovascular instability due to her history of AFib with RVR and hypotension.
* She is also at risk for respiratory failure and worsening respiratory acidosis due to her underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and acute respiratory failure.
* The patient may be at risk for further deterioration of her renal function due to her current creatinine level and underlying conditions.
* She may also be at risk for further complications from her C. difficile colitis and VAP, including sepsis and multi-organ failure.

**Plan:**

* Continue to monitor the patient's cardiovascular and respiratory status closely and adjust treatment as needed.
* Continue empiric treatment for VAP and C. difficile colitis until results are available.
* Consider diuresis once the patient is stable and hypotension is controlled.
* Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust treatment as needed.
* Consider PICC line placement to improve access for further treatment.
* Continue to communicate with the patient's husband, who is her healthcare proxy, regarding her condition and treatment plan.

   72 yo female h/o DM, HLD, HTN, Afib with RVR, s/p pacemaker and sarcoid
   presents with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema.
   Patient with multiple episodes of AFib with RVR and hypotension since
   admission, including yesterday evening. She was sent for cath and found
   to have 2 vessel disease, s/p BMS to LAD.  She now is intubated, on
   some sedation, and continues to have volatile blood pressure control
   and episodes of Afib with RVR.
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient with continued episodes of Afib with RVR with
   hemodynamic instability.
   - Will d/c the dilt drip at this time and start metoprolol 100mg po
   TID, will also give 5mg IV lopressor bolus at this time
   - Since patient has a DDD pacemaker, will not hold back on nodal agents
   as needed for RVR, as patient will be paced out of bradycardia.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - INR at goal of [**1-29**] today (INR=2.5), will continue home dose of
   coumadin
   - Will continue to rate control per EP
   - Contact outside cardiologist and pulmonologist for ?amiodarone
   # CORONARIES: NSTEMI: found to have 2 vessel disease on cardiac cath
   s/p BMS to the mid LAD. ? whether this was a primary coronary event or
   demand [**1-28**] RVR as pt. had acute heart failure yesterday and still has
   not significantly increased her troponin, would have expected large
   bump by now if infarct large enough to cause LV failure. EKG does
   appear to be c/w s/p anterior infarct.   TTE yesterday showed normal
   EF, focal hypokinesis of apical free wall of RV, and severe pulmonary
   systolic hypertension.
   - Integrillin gtt has now stopped
   - Completed ASA desensitization yesterday
   - Switched Plavix 75 mg to daily instead of [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Simvistatin 80 mg daily
   - Metoprolol to start today per above
   - Hold ACE for now, given her hypotension, dye in cath, and bump in
   creatinine
   .
   # PUMP: EF of >55% per TTE yesterday. Current BNP.  Fluid overload
   possibly secondary afib with RVR; this is likely the etiology behind
   her flash pulmonary edema.  She is likely still fluid overloaded, but
   has been hypotensive with MAPs in the 50
s overnight.
   - Will hold diuresis as patient is hypotensive and currently in Afib
   with RVR
   - Once stable, will consider diuresing again
   - Started on stress dose steroids in order to supplement BP given
   possibility of adrenal insufficiency
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Intubated s/p flash pulmonary edema in OSH;
   possibly secondary to Acute dCHF and complicated by severe pulmonary
   hypertension
   - intubated on AC; can attempt PS again today and ultimately wean from
   vent when HD stable
   - Serial ABG's
   - CXR in AM
   -  Will avoid albuterol [**1-28**] terbutaline allergy
   .
   #Anemia: Continues to trend down. Unable to guaiac stool (no BM). At
   this time thought to be secondary to marrow suppression.
   - Trend HCT
   # Respiratory Acidosis with Metabolic Compensation: Patient h/o COPD on
   home oxygen secondary to sarcoidosis. Acid/Base disturbance likely
   secondary to COPD, as patient may be a CO2 retainer.
   - Continue to monitor with ABG's
   - Adjust major acid/base disturbances with ventilation manipulation
   .
   # Fever/Leukocytosis: Patient still febrile to 102.2 with resolution of
   her leukocytosis (WBC 8.7 this am).  Being treated with Vanc/Cefepime
   and now with positive blood cultures of GPC.  Urine cx neg, sputum
   showed oropharyngeal flora.
   - Continue Vanc/cefepime (Day [**2-2**])
   - Will stop flagyl at this time as concern for C Diff low
   - Antibiotics approval received for Vanc/Cefepime
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: Patient with bump in creatinine today to 1.5
   (from 1.1 yesterday), likely prerenal etiology as consistently
   hypotensive overnight.  [**Month (only) 51**] also be related to dye given during cath,
   and possible septic shock.
   - Will calculate FeUrea to evaluated for prerenal etiology
   - Monitor creatinine daily
   - Continue to support BP for increased renal perfusion
   - Rate control her Afib to increased forward flow from heart
   # Sarcoidosis: On home O2 3LNC; currently stable; patient intubated
   - Switched to stress dose steroids
   - H/o hypercalcemia -> will continue fosamax q weekly
   .
   # Diabetes type 2: Will hold metformin and glipizide for now.
   Fingersticks 231-332, not well-controlled.
   -Start humulog ISS for more predictable control, will add lantus dose
   for basal insulin
   -FSBS qac and qhs

   # Dyslipidemia: Lipid panel drawn yesterday (see above)
   - Holding zetia for now
   - On simvastatin 80 mg daily
   # Hypothyroidism:
   -Continue Synthroid at 25 mcg daily
   # Depression:
   -Continue Paroxetine 10 mg daily
   # GERD:

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and atrial fibrillation (Afib) with rapid ventricular response (RVR). She was admitted with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. She has had multiple episodes of Afib with RVR and hypotension since admission, including yesterday evening. She was sent for cardiac catheterization and found to have 2-vessel disease, with a stent placed in the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. She is currently intubated and on sedation, with ongoing episodes of Afib with RVR and hemodynamic instability.

Medical Complications:

1. Afib with RVR: The patient has had multiple episodes of Afib with RVR, which has led to hemodynamic instability and hypotension.
2. Flash pulmonary edema: The patient developed flash pulmonary edema, which is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate treatment.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient has developed acute renal failure, likely due to prerenal etiology, septic shock, and/or dye given during cardiac catheterization.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and on assisted ventilation, with ongoing respiratory failure.
5. Fever and leukocytosis: The patient has developed a fever and leukocytosis, which may be secondary to a bacterial infection.
6. Anemia: The patient has developed anemia, likely due to marrow suppression.
7. Dyslipidemia: The patient has dyslipidemia, which may be contributing to her cardiovascular disease.
8. Hypothyroidism: The patient has hypothyroidism, which may be contributing to her cardiovascular disease.
9. Depression: The patient has depression, which may be affecting her mental health and quality of life.
10. GERD: The patient has gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which may be contributing to her respiratory symptoms.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's Afib with RVR may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, such as ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.
2. Heart failure: The patient's acute heart failure may lead to chronic heart failure, which may require further treatment.
3. Pulmonary hypertension: The patient's severe pulmonary hypertension may lead to pulmonary artery rupture or other complications.
4. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may lead to chronic renal failure, which may require further treatment.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may lead to chronic respiratory failure, which may require further treatment.
6. Infection: The patient's fever and leukocytosis may lead to a bacterial infection, which may require further treatment.
7. Bleeding: The patient's anticoagulation therapy may lead to bleeding, which may require further treatment.

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and cardiac rhythm.
2. Continue to provide supportive care, including oxygen therapy and assisted ventilation.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust her fluid and electrolyte management accordingly.
4. Consider switching to a beta blocker for rate control of Afib.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and adjust her insulin therapy accordingly.
6. Consider starting stress dose steroids to supplement the patient's adrenal function.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory function and adjust her ventilator settings accordingly.
8. Consider placing a pulmonary artery catheter to monitor the patient's cardiac output and pulmonary artery pressures.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's infection status and adjust her antibiotic therapy accordingly.
10. Consider placing a central venous catheter to provide central venous access for further therapy.

   her flash pulmonary edema.  She is likely still fluid overloaded, but

s overnight.

   - intubated on AC; can attempt PS again today and ultimately wean from

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

* The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, heart failure, and sarcoidosis, who presented with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema.
* She has been experiencing multiple episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (Afib with RVR) and hypotension since admission, including yesterday evening.
* She was intubated and on sedation, and continues to have volatile blood pressure control and episodes of Afib with RVR.
* Her labs show elevated troponin and creatinine levels, and she has a history of dyslipidemia, hypertension, and hyperthyroidism.
* She has been treated with various medications, including diuretics, vasopressors, and antiarrhythmics, and has had multiple blood cultures and sputum cultures drawn.
* She is currently being treated for sepsis with vancomycin and cefepime, and has a pending diagnosis of pneumonia.
* She has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and is on home oxygen therapy, and has been intubated for respiratory failure.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Continued instability in blood pressure and heart rhythm, which could lead to further cardiac complications.
* Respiratory failure, which could worsen with continued intubation and mechanical ventilation.
* Sepsis, which could lead to multi-organ dysfunction and septic shock.
* Acute kidney injury, which could worsen with continued hypotension and fluid overload.
* Pneumonia, which could worsen with continued respiratory failure and potential development of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
* Adrenal insufficiency, which could worsen with continued stress dose steroids and potential development of adrenal crisis.
* Hypercalcemia, which could worsen with continued fosamax therapy and potential development of hypercalcemic crisis.

Based on this information, it is recommended that the patient continue to receive close monitoring and treatment in the ICU, with adjustments to her medications and therapy as needed to manage her complex medical condition.

   72 yo female h/o DM, HLD, HTN, Afib with RVR, s/p pacemaker and sarcoid
   presents with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema.
   Patient with multiple episodes of AFib with RVR and hypotension since
   admission, including yesterday evening. She was sent for cath and found
   to have 2 vessel disease, s/p BMS to LAD.  She now is intubated, on
   some sedation, and continues to have volatile blood pressure control
   and episodes of Afib with RVR.
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient with continued episodes of Afib with RVR with
   hemodynamic instability.
   - Dilt gtt restarted this morning at 10mg/hr, will titrate to maintain
   HR < 110;
   - Since patient has a DDD pacemaker, will not hold back on nodal agents
   as needed for RVR, as patient will be paced out of bradycardia.
   - Will restart Neo gtt as necessary to maintain MAP > 60
   - Consider low dose metroprolol later today if BP stabilizes
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - INR at goal of [**1-29**] today (INR=2.5), will continue home dose of
   coumadin
   - Will continue to rate control per EP
   - Contact outside cardiologist and pulmonologist for ?amiodarone
   # CORONARIES: NSTEMI: found to have 2 vessel disease on cardiac cath
   s/p BMS to the mid LAD. ? whether this was a primary coronary event or
   demand [**1-28**] RVR as pt. had acute heart failure yesterday and still has
   not significantly increased her troponin, would have expected large
   bump by now if infarct large enough to cause LV failure. EKG does
   appear to be c/w s/p anterior infarct.   TTE yesterday showed normal
   EF, focal hypokinesis of apical free wall of RV, and severe pulmonary
   systolic hypertension.
   - Integrillin gtt has now stopped
   - Completed ASA desensitization yesterday
   - Switched Plavix 75 mg to daily instead of [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Simvistatin 80 mg daily
   - Start metroprolol low dose later today if BP tolerates
   - Hold ACE for now, given her hypotension, dye in cath, and bump in
   creatinine
   .
   # PUMP: EF of >55% per TTE yesterday. Current BNP.  Fluid overload
   possibly secondary afib with RVR; this is likely the etiology behind
   her flash pulmonary edema.  She is likely still fluid overloaded, but
   has been hypotensive with MAPs in the 50
s overnight.
   - Will hold diuresis as patient is hypotensive and currently in Afib
   with RVR
   - Once stable, will consider diuresing again
   - Started on stress dose steroids in order to supplement BP given
   possibility of adrenal insufficiency
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Intubated s/p flash pulmonary edema in OSH;
   possibly secondary to Acute dCHF and complicated by severe pulmonary
   hypertension
   - intubated on AC; can attempt PS again today and ultimately wean from
   vent when HD stable
   - Serial ABG's
   - CXR in AM
   -  Will avoid albuterol [**1-28**] terbutaline allergy
   # Respiratory Acidosis with Metabolic Compensation: Patient h/o COPD on
   home oxygen secondary to sarcoidosis. Acid/Base disturbance likely
   secondary to COPD, as patient may be a CO2 retainer.
   - Continue to monitor with ABG's
   - Adjust major acid/base disturbances with ventilation manipulation
   .
   # Fever/Leukocytosis: Patient still febrile to 102.2 with resolution of
   her leukocytosis (WBC 8.7 this am).  Being treated with Vanc/Cefepime
   and now with positive blood cultures of GPC.  Urine cx neg, sputum
   showed oropharyngeal flora.
   - Continue Vanc/cefepime (Day [**2-2**])
   - Continue Flagyl for possible C Diff infection, as cannot rule that
   out
   - Antibiotics approval received for Vanc/Cefepime
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: Patient with bump in creatinine today to 1.5
   (from 1.1 yesterday), likely prerenal etiology as consistently
   hypotensive overnight.  [**Month (only) 51**] also be related to dye given during cath,
   and possible septic shock.
   - Will calculate FeUrea to evaluated for prerenal etiology
   - Monitor creatinine daily
   - Continue to support BP for increased renal perfusion
   - Rate control her Afib to increased forward flow from heart
   # Sarcoidosis: On home O2 3LNC; currently stable; patient intubated
   - Switched to stress dose steroids
   - H/o hypercalcemia -> will continue fosamax q weekly
   .
   # Diabetes type 2: Will hold metformin and glipizide for now.

Based on the patient's 24-hour progress note, I summarize the key information as follows:

**Cardiovascular Status:**

* The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (Afib with RVR), which has been ongoing since admission.
* The patient has been intubated and is on mechanical ventilation.
* The patient has had multiple episodes of Afib with RVR and hypotension, including yesterday evening.
* The patient has a DDD pacemaker, which may affect the management of Afib with RVR.

**Respiratory Status:**

* The patient is intubated and on assisted control ventilation (ACV) due to flash pulmonary edema and severe pulmonary hypertension.
* The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and is on home oxygen.

**Renal Status:**

* The patient has a bump in creatinine to 1.5, likely due to prerenal etiology, hypotension, and possible septic shock.
* The patient is on stress dose steroids to support blood pressure and increase renal perfusion.

**Infectious Status:**

* The patient has positive blood cultures for Gram-positive cocci (GPC) and is being treated with vancomycin and cefepime.
* The patient has a history of oropharyngeal flora in the sputum culture.

**Metabolic Status:**

* The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes and is being managed with metformin and glipizide.
* The patient is being treated with insulin sliding scale (ISS) and will be started on Humalog ISS for more predictable control.

**Other Conditions:**

* The patient has a history of sarcoidosis, which may be contributing to her respiratory and cardiovascular symptoms.
* The patient has a history of hypercalcemia and is being treated with fosamax.
* The patient has a history of depression and is being treated with paroxetine.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Sepsis and septic shock due to GPC bacteremia
* Acute kidney injury due to hypotension and possible septic shock
* Respiratory failure due to flash pulmonary edema and severe pulmonary hypertension
* Cardiovascular instability due to Afib with RVR and hypotension
* Metabolic acidosis due to respiratory failure and possible septic shock
* Infection-related complications, such as pneumonia or sepsis, due to the patient's respiratory and cardiovascular status.

Based on this information, I recommend the following:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiovascular and respiratory status closely, as well as her renal function and metabolic status.
2. Consider restarting the patient on diuresis once her blood pressure stabilizes and her fluid overload is managed.
3. Continue to manage the patient's Afib with RVR with rate control measures, such as beta blockers, and consider antiarrhythmic medications if necessary.
4. Consider switching the patient to a different antibiotic regimen if the current regimen is not effective in treating the GPC bacteremia.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's glucose levels and adjust her insulin therapy as necessary.
6. Consider placing a PICC line to improve vascular access for further testing and treatment.
7. Continue to provide supportive care, including oxygen therapy, pain management, and stress ulcer prophylaxis.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and sarcoidosis, who presented with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. She has been intubated and is on sedation, with ongoing episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (Afib with RVR) and hypotension. The patient has undergone cardiac catheterization and was found to have 2-vessel disease, with a stent placed in the mid-left anterior descending artery. She is currently being treated with metoprolol, and stress dose steroids have been started to supplement her blood pressure.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Continued episodes of Afib with RVR, which can lead to further hemodynamic instability and potential cardiac arrest.
2. Hypotension, which can exacerbate underlying cardiac and renal dysfunction.
3. Respiratory failure, particularly given the patient's history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and flash pulmonary edema.
4. Acute renal failure, which may be related to prerenal etiology, dye given during catheterization, and possible septic shock.
5. Sepsis, given the positive blood cultures and ongoing fever.
6. C. difficile colitis, given the patient's recent antibiotic use and the presence of GPC in her blood cultures.
7. Adrenal insufficiency, given the patient's history of sarcoidosis and the use of stress dose steroids.
8. Hyperglycemia, given the patient's history of diabetes and the potential for glucose fluctuations with the use of insulin and other medications.
9. Dyslipidemia, given the patient's history of hyperlipidemia and the potential for medication interactions.
10. Hypothyroidism, given the patient's history of hypothyroidism and the potential for medication interactions.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient will continue to be monitored closely for signs of cardiac instability, respiratory failure, and acute renal failure. She will be treated with metoprolol to control her Afib, and stress dose steroids will be continued to supplement her blood pressure. The patient will also receive antibiotics to treat her positive blood cultures, and her blood pressure will be closely monitored to prevent further hypotension. The patient's respiratory status will be closely monitored, and she will be weaned from the ventilator when her hemodynamic status stabilizes. The patient's nutritional status will be closely monitored, and she will receive tube feeds to ensure adequate caloric intake.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), who presented with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. She was intubated and sedated, and her AFib was controlled with metoprolol and amiodarone. She has a history of sarcoidosis and is on oxygen therapy.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 100.2°F (37.9°C), heart rate of 67 bpm, and blood pressure of 95/43 mmHg. Her oxygen saturation is 97% on 40% FiO2.

The patient has multiple medical conditions, including coronary artery disease, acute renal failure, anemia, and dyslipidemia. She is being treated with a variety of medications, including metoprolol, amiodarone, plavix, simvastatin, and fosamax.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, with a WBC of 15.0 x 10^9/L. Her blood cultures are positive for Staphylococcus coagulase-negative, and her urine culture is negative. Her creatinine level has decreased from 1.5 to 1.1 mg/dL, indicating improvement in her renal function.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a PEEP of 10 cmH2O and an FiO2 of 40%. Her ABG results show a pH of 7.39, pCO2 of 34 mmHg, and pO2 of 277 mmHg.

The patient's plan includes continuing metoprolol and amiodarone, monitoring her INR, and adjusting her medications as necessary. She will also continue to receive antibiotics for her positive blood cultures, and will have serial ABG's and chest X-rays to monitor her respiratory status.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but she may be at risk for respiratory failure if her oxygen saturation decreases or if she develops a respiratory infection.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level has decreased, but she may be at risk for acute kidney injury if her blood pressure decreases or if she develops a urinary tract infection.
3. Sepsis: The patient's blood cultures are positive, and she may be at risk for sepsis if her infection is not adequately treated.
4. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's AFib is controlled, but she may be at risk for cardiac arrhythmias if her medications are not adjusted properly.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient is at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding due to her anticoagulation therapy and her history of bleeding disorders.
6. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to her indwelling catheters and her compromised immune system.
7. Hypoglycemia: The patient's blood glucose level is unstable, and she may be at risk for hypoglycemia if her insulin dose is not adjusted properly.
8. Hypothyroidism: The patient's thyroid function is suppressed, and she may be at risk for hypothyroidism if her thyroid hormone replacement therapy is not adjusted properly.

Overall, the patient's medical status is complex, and she requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (Afib with RVR). She was admitted with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. She has undergone a pacemaker implant and has 2-vessel disease with a stent in the left anterior descending (LAD) artery.

Recent events:

* The patient's rhythm has been controlled with metoprolol and amiodarone, with a sinus rhythm for approximately 24 hours.
* She has had multiple episodes of Afib with RVR and hypotension since admission.
* She was sent for cardiac catheterization and found to have 2-vessel disease, which was treated with a stent in the LAD artery.
* She has been intubated and sedated, and is currently on mechanical ventilation.
* She has a fever and leukocytosis, with positive blood cultures for coagulase-negative Staphylococcus.
* She has been treated with vancomycin and cefepime, and has had a mucus plug removed from her airway.
* She has been experiencing respiratory failure, with a need for mechanical ventilation.
* She has been experiencing acute kidney injury, with a decrease in creatinine from 1.5 to 1.1.
* She has been experiencing anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 25.

Assessment and Plan:

* Continue metoprolol 100mg po TID and amiodarone 400mg po BID.
* Monitor on telemetry.
* INR goal of 2.0-2.5, with a plan to stop coumadin and allow INR to drift to 2.0-2.5.
* Continue vancomycin and cefepime for 3-4 days, with a plan to switch to oral antibiotics if cultures are negative.
* Continue to monitor creatinine and adjust dosing of vancomycin and cefepime accordingly.
* Consider diuresis once stable.
* Continue to support blood pressure with stress dose steroids.
* Rate control her Afib to increase forward flow from the heart.
* Continue to monitor for signs of sepsis and adjust treatment accordingly.

Potential Medical Complications:

* Continued respiratory failure and need for mechanical ventilation.
* Acute kidney injury and need for ongoing renal support.
* Anemia and potential need for blood transfusions.
* Continued risk of sepsis and need for ongoing antibiotic therapy.
* Potential for further cardiac complications, including arrhythmias and heart failure.
* Potential for further respiratory complications, including pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome.
* Potential for further gastrointestinal complications, including nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.
* Potential for further hematological complications, including bleeding and coagulopathy.

Note: The patient's medical history and current condition suggest a high risk of complications, and ongoing monitoring and treatment will be necessary to manage these risks and prevent further complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and sarcoidosis who presented with acute heart failure and flash pulmonary edema. She was intubated and sedated and had multiple episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. She was found to have 2-vessel coronary disease and underwent balloon angioplasty and stenting to the mid-left anterior descending artery.

The patient's condition has been stable over the past 24 hours, with conversion to sinus rhythm and resolution of her leukocytosis. She is still febrile, with a temperature of 100.2°F, and has positive blood cultures for Gram-positive cocci. She is being treated with vancomycin and cefepime, and her antibiotics have been approved.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with improvement in her lung sounds and oxygen saturation. She is still intubated and on mechanical ventilation, but her ABG results are stable. Her cardiac status is stable, with a normal ejection fraction and no signs of cardiac failure.

The patient's laboratory results are stable, with no significant changes in her electrolyte levels or kidney function. Her hemoglobin level is stable, and her platelet count is normal. Her liver function tests are normal, and her lactate level is within normal limits.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's positive blood cultures and febrile response suggest the possibility of sepsis. Close monitoring of her vital signs and laboratory results is necessary to detect any signs of sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but she is still intubated and on mechanical ventilation. Close monitoring of her respiratory status is necessary to detect any signs of respiratory failure.
3. Cardiac failure: The patient's cardiac status is stable, but she has a history of heart failure and is at risk for cardiac failure. Close monitoring of her cardiac status is necessary to detect any signs of cardiac failure.
4. Kidney failure: The patient's kidney function is stable, but she has a history of kidney disease and is at risk for kidney failure. Close monitoring of her kidney function is necessary to detect any signs of kidney failure.
5. Sarcoidosis: The patient has a history of sarcoidosis, which is a chronic inflammatory disease that can affect any organ in the body. Close monitoring of her symptoms and laboratory results is necessary to detect any signs of sarcoidosis.
6. Diabetes: The patient has a history of diabetes, which is a chronic condition that requires close monitoring of her blood glucose levels. Close monitoring of her blood glucose levels is necessary to detect any signs of hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia.

Overall, the patient's condition is stable, but she is at risk for various medical complications. Close monitoring of her vital signs, laboratory results, and symptoms is necessary to detect any signs of these complications and to provide appropriate treatment.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), who presents with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. She was admitted to the ICU with multiple episodes of AFib with RVR and hypotension since admission. She was found to have 2-vessel disease and underwent balloon angioplasty and stenting (BMS) to the mid-left anterior descending (LAD) artery. The patient is currently intubated and sedated, with a diagnosis of acute diastolic heart failure (ADHF) and severe pulmonary hypertension.

Medical Complications:

1. Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR): The patient's AFib with RVR has not been well-controlled, leading to inadequate rate control and hypotension.
2. Acute diastolic heart failure (ADHF): The patient's ADHF is likely secondary to AFib with RVR and severe pulmonary hypertension.
3. Flash pulmonary edema: The patient's flash pulmonary edema is likely secondary to ADHF and severe pulmonary hypertension.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level is elevated, likely due to hypervolemic hypernatremia.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely secondary to marrow suppression.
6. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure is likely secondary to hypotension in the setting of AFib with RVR.
7. Sarcoidosis: The patient has a history of sarcoidosis, which is likely exacerbating her pulmonary hypertension and heart failure.
8. Diabetes: The patient's diabetes is not well-controlled, with blood sugars in the 300s-400s.
9. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's lipid panel shows TC 157, TG 156, HDL 30, and LDLc 96, indicating dyslipidemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's history of AFib with RVR and flash pulmonary edema increases her risk of developing pneumonia.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely secondary to ADHF and severe pulmonary hypertension, and may worsen if not managed appropriately.
3. Cardiac arrest: The patient's AFib with RVR and ADHF increase her risk of cardiac arrest.
4. Sepsis: The patient's history of AFib with RVR and flash pulmonary edema increases her risk of developing sepsis.
5. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen if not managed appropriately.

Plan:

1. Continue metoprolol 100mg po TID to control AFib with RVR.
2. Continue amiodarone 400mg [**Hospital1 7**] to control AFib with RVR.
3. Monitor on telemetry to ensure adequate rate control.
4. Wean metoprolol to [**Hospital1 7**] at 5 grams of amiodorone is in system...Sunday.
5. Continue Vanc/Cefepime (Day [**4-2**]) and monitor for further culture and sensitivities.
6. Consider restarting flagyl or double coverage for pseudomonas if leukocytosis returns.
7. Continue stress dose steroids to support BP and possibly adrenal insufficiency.
8. Monitor creatinine daily and continue to support BP for increased renal perfusion.
9. Rate control AFib with RVR to increase forward flow from heart.
10. Continue simvastatin 80mg daily and consider holding zetia.
11. Continue Synthroid at 25 mcg daily.
12. Continue Paroxetine 10mg daily.
13. Start H2 blocker (Famotidine) as PPI interacts with Plavix.
14. Continue regular insulin gtt until blood sugar well-controlled.
15. Trend HCT daily and transfuse <21.
16. Monitor glycemic control and adjust insulin gtt as needed.
17. Continue stress dose steroids and monitor for adrenal insufficiency.
18. Continue to support BP and consider starting heparin gtt.
19. Monitor for signs of sepsis and adjust antibiotic therapy as needed.
20. Continue to monitor for respiratory failure and adjust therapy as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and sarcoidosis. She was admitted with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. She has been intubated and sedated, and has had multiple episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.

The patient's current condition is:

* Respiratory: Intubated, on PS 5/5 with decent ABG and RSBI
* Cardiac: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, stable BP
* Renal: Acute renal failure, Cr 1.1, likely secondary to hypotension and pre-renal etiology
* Endocrine: Hypernatremia, likely hypervolemic, free water deficit
* Hematological: Anemia, Hct 26, stable
* Pulmonary: Severe sarcoidosis, tiny left pleural effusion
* Gastrointestinal: GERD, starting H2 blocker
* Neurological: Depressed mental status, not responsive to pain or verbal stimuli
* Medications: Metoprolol, diltiazem, amiodarone, heparin, insulin, lasix, flagyl, simvastatin, aspirin, Plavix, Synthroid, paroxetine

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: continued respiratory support may be necessary
* Cardiac complications: atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response may lead to cardiac arrest or stroke
* Renal failure: acute renal failure may progress to chronic renal failure if not managed properly
* Electrolyte imbalance: hypernatremia may lead to seizures or cardiac arrhythmias
* Infection: positive blood cultures may indicate sepsis or endocarditis
* Gastrointestinal complications: GERD may lead to aspiration or bleeding
* Neurological complications: depressed mental status may worsen or lead to brain injury
* Hematological complications: anemia may worsen or lead to bleeding
* Pulmonary complications: severe sarcoidosis may lead to respiratory failure or fibrosis
* Endocrine complications: hypernatremia may lead to seizures or cardiac arrhythmias

Recommendations:

* Continue respiratory support with PS 5/5 and serial ABG's
* Monitor cardiac rhythm and control atrial fibrillation with rate-controlling medications
* Manage renal failure with diuretics and continue to support BP
* Monitor electrolyte imbalance and correct as necessary
* Continue antibiotics for positive blood cultures and monitor for signs of sepsis
* Monitor for gastrointestinal complications and adjust medication as necessary
* Continue to support neurological status with sedation and analgesia
* Monitor for hematological complications and transfuse as necessary
* Monitor for pulmonary complications and adjust oxygen therapy as necessary

   72 yo female h/o DM, HLD, HTN, Afib with RVR, s/p pacemaker and sarcoid
   presents with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema.
   Patient with multiple episodes of AFib with RVR and hypotension since
   admission. She was sent for cath and found to have 2 vessel disease,
   s/p BMS to LAD.  She now is intubated, sedated. AFib overnight with
   inadequate rate control.
   .
   # RHYTHM: Sinus for approx. 24 hours. EKG with long QTc.  Patient in
   afib with rates in the 100s to 120s starting at midnight; 10 mg IV
   metoprolol and 10 mg of IV dilt did not help decrease the rate. Patient
   with stable BP.
   - Continue Metoprolol 100mg po TID; once she has 5 grams of amio, will
   cut back metoprolol to [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Continue Amiodarone 400mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - INR at goal of [**1-29**], today (INR=2.6), since patient will be long term
   in CCU, will stop coumadin and allow drift of INR to 2
 will start
   Heparin gtt as INR is 1.8 today.
   - Will need to place PICC at that time.
   -Will wean metoprolol to [**Hospital1 7**] at 5 grams of amiodorone is in
   system...Sunday.
   # CORONARIES: NSTEMI: 2 vessel disease s/p BMS to the mid LAD.
   - Plavix 75 mg Daily
   - Simvistatin 80 mg daily
   -  ASA 325 mg Daily
   - Metoprolol to start today per above
   - Hold ACE for now, one more day without hypotension and good urine
   output.
   .
   # Fever/Leukocytosis: Patient afebrile overnight with an increase in
   wbc from 5.1 to 13.7.  Being treated with Vanc/Cefepime and with
   positive blood cultures of coag negative staph in
 bottles. Still
   waiting for further culture and sensitivities.  Urine cx neg, sputum
   showed oropharyngeal flora.
   - Fu Blood Cultures (7/22,[**7-18**],) and Sputum ([**7-17**], [**7-19**]).
   - FU sensitivities from positive blood culture
   - Continue Vanc/cefepime (Day [**4-2**]); Vanc level high and last nights
   vanc dose was held. Will continue to monitor
   - Stopped flagyl;
   -  with return of leukocytosis consider restarting flagyl or double
   coverage for pseudomonus
   - Antibiotics approval received for Vanc/Cefepime
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Intubated s/p flash pulmonary edema in OSH;
   possibly secondary to Acute dCHF and complicated by severe pulmonary
   hypertension. Mucus plug removed yesterday.
   - Currently on PS 5/5 with decent ABG and RSBI this AM. If mental
   status improves off sedation, consider extubation today.
   - Serial ABG's
   -  Will avoid albuterol [**1-28**] terbutaline allergy
   - Pulmonary following
appreciate recs
   - Lung CT scan w/o contrast per Pulmonary shows severe sarcoid. Will
   obtain old CT/PFT from outpatient pulmonologist on Monday to help
   better assess disease progression.
   .
   # PUMP: EF of >55% per TTE yesterday. Fluid overload possibly secondary
   afib with RVR; this is likely the etiology behind her flash pulmonary
   edema.  . Patient appeared fluid overloaded and s/p 20 mg IV lasix at
   1800 (UOP of 400 cc) and 2200 (UOP 200cc); -220 cc since
   midnight
positive 4.5 liters LOS; patient appears fluid overloaded
   - Will diurese today: 40 mg IV lasix and re-assess from there as
   patient appears fluid overloaded
   - Started on stress dose steroids in order to supplement BP given
   possibility of adrenal insufficiency
   .
   #Anemia: Stable; Hct 26. Unable to guaiac stool (no BM). At this time
   thought to be secondary to marrow suppression.
   -          Trend HCT daily
   -          Transfuse < 21.
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: Crt stable at 1.1. Most likely secondary to
   hypotension in setting of afib rvr.  FeUrea 8.16% is consistent with
   pre renal etiology..
   - Monitor creatinine daily
   - Continue to support BP for increased renal perfusion
   - Rate control her Afib to increased forward flow from heart
   # Sarcoidosis: On home O2 3LNC; currently stable; patient intubated
   - Switched to stress dose steroids
   - H/o hypercalcemia -> will continue fosamax q weekly
   .
   # Diabetes type 2: Will hold metformin and glipizide for now.  Sliding
   scale with 26 units of lantus not well controlled as fsbs in the
   300s-400s. Insulin gtt started in evening and improving blood sugars.
   Trending down from 415 to 178.
   - continue insulin gtt until blood sugar well controlled. Once at
   optimal level (120-180) will transition to more aggressive sliding
   scale based on amount of insulin needed in past 24 hours.
   .
   # Dyslipidemia: Lipid panel shows TC 157, TG: 156 HDL 30 LDLc 96; Not
   optimal HDL/LDL level
   - Holding zetia for now
   - Continue simvastatin 80 mg daily
   # Hypothyroidism:
   -Continue Synthroid at 25 mcg daily
   # Depression:
   -Continue Paroxetine 10 mg daily
   # GERD:
   -Start H2 blocker (Famotidine) as PPI interacts with Plavix
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: On tube feeds now at goal.  Held at 0400 for hopes to
   extubate
   Glycemic Control: Regular Insulin gtt

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and atrial fibrillation (AFib) who presented with acute heart failure leading to flash pulmonary edema. She was intubated and sedated, and her AFib was not well-controlled. The patient has multiple comorbidities, including sarcoidosis, coronary artery disease, and anemia.

The patient's condition has been unstable, with episodes of hypotension, tachycardia, and AFib. She has been treated with various medications, including metoprolol, diltiazem, and amiodarone, to control her heart rate and rhythm. The patient's blood sugar levels have been unstable, and she has been started on insulin therapy.

The patient's respiratory status has been compromised, with a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute and a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 238. She has been on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and has had a partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 56 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results have been notable for an elevated white blood cell count, with a peak value of 13.7 x 10^9/L. Her blood cultures have been positive for coagulase-negative Staphylococcus aureus, and she has been treated with vancomycin and cefepime.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's AFib and coronary artery disease may lead to further cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, or myocardial infarction.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory status may continue to deteriorate, leading to further respiratory failure or pneumonia.
3. Infectious complications: The patient's positive blood cultures and elevated white blood cell count may indicate a systemic infection, which could lead to sepsis or organ failure.
4. Endocrine complications: The patient's diabetes and hypothyroidism may lead to further complications, such as hyperglycemia or hypothyroidism.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's gastrointestinal symptoms, such as nausea and vomiting, may worsen, leading to further complications, such as dehydration or malnutrition.
6. Renal complications: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen, leading to further complications, such as chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's sedation and respiratory status may lead to further neurological complications, such as delirium or coma.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust her medications as necessary to control her AFib.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust her ventilator settings as necessary to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's blood sugar levels and adjust her insulin therapy as necessary to maintain euglycemia.
4. Consider starting the patient on stress dose steroids to supplement her adrenal function.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust her medications as necessary to maintain normal electrolyte levels.
6. Consider starting the patient on prophylactic antibiotics to prevent further infections.
7. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal symptoms and adjust her medications as necessary to prevent further complications.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust her medications as necessary to prevent further complications.
9. Monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust her sedation as necessary to prevent further complications.

 bottles. Still
